title: Catharsis Is Overrated
html:

Homepage
Sign inGet started

Catharsis Is Overrated

How to suck at processing your last relationship

Kyle Turner
Mar 27

I’m having trouble writing about my last relationship. I tried to write something about it very recently for a contest, but I knew it was bad, and it was a slog to write, and most of it felt artificially sentimental and calculated. I got some constructive criticism from my best friend Phuong; there was something missing. I don’t know what. I’m screaming at my laptop, ready to throw it out the window, paralyzed by my inability to write about this. I’ve started and stopped and started again and gotten distracted by Grindr and decided to have some soup and started again and then stopped and — wait, what?

Oh yeah, I’m to figure out how to write about him. Conner.

But I digress. I’m having an issue not digressing. I’m having trouble deciding if “relationship” is an appropriate label for what Conner and I had. It’s easy to give into his emotional unavailability and just say we had a “dynamic,” which sounds prissy. But that dynamic resembled, mirrored, felt like any relationship between two significant others I’d ever seen or imagined. It was a relationship to me, but maybe the shadow of one to him. So, I’m having trouble writing about what we had. I’m having trouble writing anything about what happened over those two and a half years beyond some trite, easy narrative about naiveté and long distance and desire.

I’m having trouble putting into the words the magnetic quality I felt he had, how his charisma transcended the limitations of the internet. I’m having trouble writing about his personality, or the way reading his writing made me feel like I’d gotten high without the health risk. I’m having a bit of trouble figuring out what exactly went wrong — between us, on the trip when I visited him in Los Angeles, when I answered his novella-length text about how he had been disappointed by our meeting. Different expectations, probably? I was too ready to commit to the most intangible things, because I’m always too ready to commit. My body aches in its desire to feel with someone, not just with myself. I wanted to feel (with) him.

Trying to fall back in love with him was like trying to forgive the Republican Party.

I’m having trouble not seeing him in annoying YouTube stars, or people on the street, or in the backgrounds of movies, or in the creases of kettle cooked potato chips.

I’m having a bit of trouble describing what it was like to transition from navigating my attraction via Skype and text to being with him in person. By then, it was too late; he’d already hurt me too many times, and trying to fall back in love with him was like trying to forgive the Republican Party.

I’m having trouble mapping the timeline: when he first tweeted me, when I first sent a tacit flirtation, when he gave me his number, when he broke my heart the first time. I’m having trouble remembering when my friends told me to stop communicating — and when I ignored my friends’ advice, as we often do. I know my relationship history (especially as a queer man) was, and is, scant. I’m having trouble articulating how pissed and nervous and elated I was when he finally said our relationship might be meaningful in the way I had always hoped. I’m having trouble describing what it felt like when he invited me to Los Angeles, and I’m having trouble writing about my ambivalence when I arrived.

I don’t have much of an issue remembering certain things: When I was in Los Angeles, I had trouble not punching Conner in the stomach. It wasn’t that he was different from the person or persona I’d gotten to know online, it’s that he was the same, even amplified. The whiny nonsense that had begun to irritate me by the time we decided to reconfigure our dynamic as more platonic (pre-Los Angeles) got to me even more in person. I had trouble dealing with his constant interruptions, his pedantic interludes, his temper tantrums.

I didn’t have trouble telling him I was in love with him. It came naturally, but it also came from pain. I also didn’t have trouble telling him, as we sat in bed together, that I didn’t want to shower with him, because I don’t want to shower with anyone. But maybe that was a lie. Maybe I knew in my heart that the illusion had been shattered.

I had trouble bringing up the topic of where we were and what we were, so we watched the presidential debates instead, as if they were more palatable. I had that problem of not talking about what we were for two years; I had an issue with asserting my desires at the risk of losing him. I thought about it a lot, rehearsed what I would say to him, looked at him through a screen, but had trouble actually speaking.

I’m frustrated with this sort of writer’s block because I was led to believe that if you write about pain in your past relationship, you can create great, cathartic art. I was told that writing about pain is the key to getting past it! They have lied to me! “They” being all the writers who’ve been in a relationship lasting more than a red Starburst who then pound away at poetry containing the words “tempest” or “maelstrom” or “freezing rain with a slight chance of thunderstorms” and then read it at a college open mic, which you only went to for the donut holes.

What Conner offered me above all was the artifice of consistency, without the substance of commitment.

But if I can’t write about it, if I don’t know how to make sense of how much he meant to me — the ludicrous way in which I sacrificed my time and heart and ignored the advice of all my close friends — I’ll wonder if I’ve squandered every good and bad thing that came out of that relationship. Yes, he was a pedantic jerk with little consideration for my feelings, but I did care about him. He did mean a lot. He does mean a lot. I value what I had with him.

I had someone who challenged me intellectually, supported my writing, and pushed me to be better. I had someone whose voice I could listen to (time zones notwithstanding), someone who offered me respite from the racist nonsense I sometimes experience in the queer community, and someone who finally convinced me to watch Mad Men. I worry that not being able to sift through the mixed feelings I have about what happened makes me a bad person.

A questionable person and a bad writer? I know there are other writers, people even, for whom processing the life and death of a relationship (in any capacity) isn’t easy. Pinpointing the transcendent and the hellish is not just a task, but a kind of job that makes you ask questions about yourself. It makes you confront your inadequacies and biases.

Since moving to New York, my thoughts return to him more often than I’d like. I’m still confused about the mess, still devoid of closure, still trying to narrativize it in some way. Millions of people pass by every day, and in six months, it feels like 12 percent of them have ghosted me. It’s hard not to want to fold into yourself, not to want, instead, to fall into someone’s arms. What Conner offered me above all was the artifice of consistency, without the substance of commitment. And maybe I offered the same thing to him.

Perhaps catharsis is overrated. I can just as easily pour my feelings into the last 12 McNugget meals I’ve had today. I don’t know what closure feels like, or will feel like. Maybe it will wash over me like the gentle waters of Cape Cod, or sprinkle on me like April rain.

Maybe it will come to me later. Or maybe it won’t. I’ll figure out how to be okay with it either way.

I think.

  • Life
  • Relationships
  • LGBTQ
  • Essay
  • Heart

  • Kyle Turner

    Snarkoleptic. Queer monster. Amateur critic. Professional snob. Freelancer. I am relieved to know that I am not a golem.

  • Human Parts

    What it means to be.

title_html: Catharsis Is Overrated
